title: For Scott Walker, a Consistent Approach Under Tough Questioning
content:
It is a rhetorical style that helped him beat back a 2012 recall vote after he sharply curtailed the power of public employee unions in his first term . Pressed during weeks of protests over the union fight , Mr. Walker defended his position in almost identical language , said Charles Franklin , the director of the Marquette Law School Poll .
“ He didn ’ t amplify , didn ’ t show how he would advance a different argument or different considerations , ” Mr. Franklin said . “ Rather , he repeated almost exactly the same statements again and again . It is effective from a messaging perspective because you only get what he wants you to get . ”
Michael W. Wagner , an assistant professor of journalism and political science at the University of Wisconsin , said that Mr. Walker frequently speaks to the news media , but that the encounters are amid gaggles of reporters without time for pointed follow-up questions . “ Local reporters have become conditioned to the idea he ’ s not going to amplify his answer , ” he said .
Craig Gilbert , the Washington bureau chief for The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel , wrote in analyzing Mr. Walker ’ s approach to the Giuliani uproar that it showed the governor ’ s “ disciplined and relentless approach to political messaging . ”
One of the rare times Mr. Walker seemed at a loss for words during his tight race for re-election last year against a liberal Democrat was when he was asked about his refusal to accept the federal Medicaid expansion . A social activism group charged that it was a favor to insurance companies that had donated generously to his campaigns , and that had gained new customers .
“ Actually if you think about it , it ’ s just the opposite , ” Mr. Walker said . “ It means fewer people would be on insurance actually , if , in the end , if there were more people there they ’ d be under Medicaid . It ’ s not a , for us , it has no decision one way or the other . ”
Mr. Walker ’ s typical response to a question he perceives as containing a barbed hook is to refuse it , adding that real voters do not ask about such issues . That is exactly how he responded to reporters ’ repeated efforts to elicit a response to Mr. Giuliani ’ s statement that “ I do not believe that the president loves America . ”
